source.query: prone Y W raises muscles worked
source.raw_text:
Prone W-Y lifts target your upper back (rhomboids, traps) and rear shoulders (rear delts), improving shoulder stability, posture, and overhead mobility by strengthening scapular stabilizers and the rotator cuff through controlled lifting motions, primarily focusing on scapular retraction and upward rotation as you transition from a "Y" (arms out) to a "W" (arms bent) position. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary: Lower Trapezius, Rhomboids, Rear Deltoids. 
• Secondary: Serratus Anterior, Rotator Cuff (Supraspinatus). [1, 2, 3, 5]  

Movement Pattern (Prone Y-W) 

1. Starting Position: Lie face down (prone) on a bench or the floor, with your forehead supported (e.g., on a towel). 
2. Y Phase: Extend your arms diagonally overhead into a "Y" shape, thumbs pointing up. Lift your arms by squeezing your shoulder blades together and down, keeping your neck relaxed. 
3. Transition to W: Keeping your arms elevated, bend your elbows to bring your hands towards your shoulders, forming a "W" shape. 
4. Return to Y: Extend your arms back out to the "Y" position. 
5. Lower: Slowly lower your arms back to the starting position. [2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

Key Focus Points 

• Scapular Control: Focus on moving your shoulder blades (scapulae) together (retraction) and upward (upward rotation). 
• Thumb Position: Keep your thumbs pointed towards the ceiling for optimal shoulder mechanics. 
• Control: Avoid shrugging your shoulders to your ears; keep them down and back. 
• Progression: Use light weights or resistance bands for increased challenge and muscle activation. [3, 6, 7, 10, 11]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://fitbod.me/exercises/prone-y-s
[2] https://fitfxtraining.ca/upper-body-exercises/prone-y-raises-exercise
